div.p: In utmost haste, truly can do nothing; so much has happened. I have received your letter, thank you diligently. My brother writes at night, the Reichstag will soon come to an end. The Emperor is in a hurry; one does not know what he has in mind.
3000 horses are supposed to come from the Netherlands to accompany Maximilian to Spain; however, it is said that something else might be behind it. May God arrange it for the best.

The one from Lier has been dispatched, it is said, to Pregetz, Lindau, Überlingen he is supposed to come; some say it is because of Savoy; the other rumor is that he is going to the Landgrave to persuade him about the Interim; otherwise, he cannot be relieved.
Esslingen has just on the 25th of May made an agreement with the king, must give 13,000 florins; had demanded 25,000.
Memmingen now gives the king 14,000 florins along with Buchshaim, the charterhouse, and a large part of their jurisdiction in the city.

Duke Maurice and Margrave Hans of Brandenburg have departed from Augsburg. Margrave Hans is said to have told the king, when they wanted to persuade him to accept the Interim: he is good imperial; but in religion, he will not let himself be forced by God and his word. Duke Christoph of Württemberg has also arrived in Augsburg; what will he accomplish there?

There is intense negotiation with Augsburg, that they want to precede others and make the entrance with the Interim; but it is assured that it will not be able to increase at all with the community; may God! In Hildesheim, the common people are completely restless against the authorities, demanding the annulment of the reconciliation. Magdeburg also now incites the common people; otherwise, they would have been expelled. May God yet throw in a hook, so that we do not come so miserably from this precious treasure of his word!

Our envoys sent the entire Interim to my lords last night; they will hear it these days. I have not yet seen it, will see how I can manage to have them allow me to copy it for you, etc. God be with you.
To Dr. Heinrich Bullinger, his venerable and dearest brother. Zurich.
